articles.headline: Xi Jinping Promotes Openness at a China Forum Rife With Restrictions
articles.snippet: The Chinese leader portrayed himself as a champion of free trade and the world order, and the global elite celebrated him.
articles.abstract: The Chinese leader portrayed himself as a champion of free trade and the world order, and the global elite celebrated him.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOAO, China — The International Monetary Fund chief praised his openness. A senior British banker lauded his authoritarian rule. The Philippine president said he loves the man.

articles.headline: Paul Ryan Upends Republican Hopes and Plans for Midterm Elections
articles.snippet: Mr. Ryan’s retirement could make it easier for Democrats to win control of the House, Republicans say. The speaker had raised more than $54 million for the 2018 elections.
articles.abstract: Mr. Ryan’s retirement could make it easier for Democrats to win control of the House, Republicans say. The speaker had raised more than $54 million for the 2018 elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Fifteen months after Republicans took full control of Washington, the man long seen as central to the party’s future is abandoning one of the most powerful jobs in the capital, imperiling the G.O.P. grip on the House and signaling that the political convulsions of the Trump era are taking a grave toll on the right months before Election Day.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: I Downloaded the Information That Facebook Has on Me. Yikes.
articles.snippet: Using a tool that Facebook offers its users, our columnist found out more than he wanted to know about the social network, the ad industry and himself.
articles.abstract: Using a tool that Facebook offers its users, our columnist found out more than he wanted to know about the social network, the ad industry and himself.
articles.lead_paragraph: When I downloaded a copy of my Facebook data last week, I didn’t expect to see much. My profile is sparse, I rarely post anything on the site, and I seldom click on ads. (I’m what some call a Facebook “lurker.”)

articles.headline: U.S. Seeks Quick Nafta Deal, but Allies Balk as It Gives Little Ground
articles.snippet: The Trump administration confronts conflicting desires: to secure a deal in time for approval by the current Congress and to keep contentious proposals on manufacturing.
articles.abstract: The Trump administration confronts conflicting desires: to secure a deal in time for approval by the current Congress and to keep contentious proposals on manufacturing.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration is pushing to reach a deal on the North American Free Trade Agreement by the beginning of May. But the timeline could be complicated by its refusal to budge from contentious proposals aimed at bringing manufacturing back to the United States.

articles.headline: Facebook Is Complicated. That Shouldn’t Stop Lawmakers.
articles.snippet: The biggest obstacle to regulating Facebook is not Congress’s lack of digital expertise. It’s a lack of political will.
articles.abstract: The biggest obstacle to regulating Facebook is not Congress’s lack of digital expertise. It’s a lack of political will.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When it comes to regulating Facebook, Congress is in over its head. But does that matter?

articles.headline: Investigators Focus on Another Trump Ally: The National Enquirer
articles.snippet: A federal inquiry is examining the relationship between a tabloid company, President Trump and his lawyer Michael D. Cohen, whose office was raided by the F.B.I.
articles.abstract: A federal inquiry is examining the relationship between a tabloid company, President Trump and his lawyer Michael D. Cohen, whose office was raided by the F.B.I.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump has long had ties to the nation’s major media players. But his connections with the country’s largest tabloid publisher, American Media Inc., run deeper than most.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg, Emily Steel and Mike McIntire

articles.headline: Trump Says Missiles ‘Will Be Coming’ at Syria. Beyond That Lies Uncertainty.
articles.snippet: A strike in response to a suspected chemical attack comes with perils that worry military planners and diplomats, and a fresh intervention in a combustible region could bring unintended consequences.
articles.abstract: A strike in response to a suspected chemical attack comes with perils that worry military planners and diplomats, and a fresh intervention in a combustible region could bring unintended consequences.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump made clear on Wednesday that missiles “will be coming” at Syria at any moment, telegraphing a military operation as he has previously said he would never do. But the real suspense remained — how many missiles, for how long, at what targets and to what end.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Mattis Tries to Put Brakes on Possible Syria Strike, to ‘Keep This From Escalating’
articles.snippet: Defense Secretary Jim Mattis demanded evidence of the Syrian government’s role in a suspected chemical attack to justify military action — and mute Russian criticism.
articles.abstract: Defense Secretary Jim Mattis demanded evidence of the Syrian government’s role in a suspected chemical attack to justify military action — and mute Russian criticism.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Jim Mattis sought on Thursday to slow down an imminent strike on Syria, reflecting mounting concerns at the Pentagon that a concerted bombing campaign could escalate into a wider conflict between Russia, Iran and the West.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Peter Baker

articles.headline: After Cambridge Analytica, Privacy Experts Get to Say ‘I Told You So’
articles.snippet: The scandal over how Facebook let a consulting firm gain access to user information is ushering in a new era for privacy experts, whose warnings about online privacy have long gone unheeded.
articles.abstract: The scandal over how Facebook let a consulting firm gain access to user information is ushering in a new era for privacy experts, whose warnings about online privacy have long gone unheeded.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif. — Doc Searls met with a group of fellow internet privacy experts one recent afternoon here at the Computer History Museum. On a whiteboard were the words “OUTRAGE” and “MAKE HAY” — capitalized, underlined and surrounded by lines jutting in all directions like a cartoon “BOOM!”

articles.headline: Want to Sell Fighter Jets to India? Make Them There
articles.snippet: India, the world’s top importer of weapons, wants to develop its local industry. U.S. companies are offering technology and new factories to win deals.
articles.abstract: India, the world’s top importer of weapons, wants to develop its local industry. U.S. companies are offering technology and new factories to win deals.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHENNAI, India — Over the last decade, India has been the world’s largest importer of aircraft, ships and other military gear, most of it from Russia.
